snippet: Some appeared critical of the decision to prosecute John L. Yates, who faced a maximum of 20 years in prison for throwing back three undersize red grouper.
abstract: Most of the Supreme Court justices hearing arguments in case of Florida fisherman John L Yates, accused of violating Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 because he threw back three undersize red grouper into Gulf of Mexico, appear critical of decision to prosecute him at all; federal law is aimed primarily at white-collar crime and Supreme Court has been wary of stretching federal laws to fit minor crimes; Yates faces 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Some appeared critical of the decision to prosecute John L. Yates, who faced a maximum of 20 years in prison for throwing back three undersize red grouper.

headline.main: Justices Consider Whether Tossing Out Fish Destroyed Records
headline.print_headline: Justices Consider Whether Tossing Out Fish Destroyed Records
